results.title: They Scream! We Scream!
results.abstract: What’s more fundamental to scary movies than the bone-chilling shriek? But delivering a terrifying wail isn’t easy. It’s an entire art with a history and a world of its own.

multimedia.copyright: Maggie Shannon for The New York Times
multimedia.caption: Susan Boyajian says there are “gradual screams, a buildup scream, kind of hyperventilating — say someone’s chasing you with a knife, and then you go into a scream.”

results.title: Black Women’s Hair and Horror Movies: What Could Go Wrong?
results.abstract: An evil weave turns a shy character into a serial killer in “Bad Hair,” but the film doesn’t understand that styling locks can be a source of intimacy and communal pride.

results.abstract: The pandemic has staggered the industry and left independent operations like the Park Plaza Cinema in Hilton Head Island, S.C., fighting to stay afloat.

results.title: How New York’s Small Cinemas Are Hanging On
results.abstract: Despite the continued shutdown of the city’s movie houses, indie theaters just may survive: They are less reliant on Hollywood and have a loyal audience.

multimedia.copyright: Calla Kessler for The New York Times
multimedia.caption: Nick Nicolaou, who owns Cinema Village, and the people behind indie cinemas like Film Forum, Anthology Film Archives and Nitehawk remain in an uneasy limbo, desperate for audiences yet terrified of cinemas becoming petri dishes.

results.title: Making the Songs Pop in ‘Bad Hair’
results.abstract: Justin Simien, the writer and director of the 1989-set horror-comedy, also wrote some of the retro-sounding songs. Though he’s known for “Dear White People,” music has long been a hobby.

multimedia.caption: Often films about teenagers with special powers focus on how overwhelmed they are, Lister-Jones said. “I don’t think that’s a message we need to be giving to young women anymore. I think the more power, the better.”
